title: Swedens WAGS stay hotel ENGLAND team
story: Swedish WAGs like Maja Nilsen (pictured) wife of Man Utd's Victor Lindelof are staying at the Renaissance with the England teamEngland's players will be staying in the same hotel as the Swedish WAGs ahead of tomorrow's World Cup quarter final, MailOnline can reveal.Harry Kane and his teammates will sleep in the 196-room Renaissance in Samara where Sweden's wives and girlfriends will also be staying.But the Swedes are bragging they already have the edge after they were booked into Samara's only five-star resort - leaving England in a more modest four-star hotel. Sweden's FA President Karl-Erik Nilsson joked: 'You could say Sweden is one-zero up already.'  His countrymen are in the Lotte Hotel, which opened in April, and is the best hotel in the area.   The hotel's sumptuous  fine food menu lists the amount of calories contained in each item for weight watchers - which even has its own caviar menu where a spoonful of Stugeon is available for £71 and a lesser 'Pike' variety for £16.Their players can also tuck into tuna with chukka seaweed salad, crab cake with tomato salsa, roast duck, creme of pumpkin soup with Kamchatka crab and cream cheese and tiger shrimp and scallop brochettes and a filet Mignion steak.          Harry Kane and his teammates will sleep in the 196-room Renaissance (pictured) in Samara where Sweden's wives and girlfriends will also be staying          England has been allocated the four-star Renaissance (foyer pictured) Hotel in Samara while their World Cup quarter final opponents are staying at the town's only five star resort           Sweden are crowing to have been allocated better accommodation than their rivals. Their FA President Karl-Erik Nilsson (left) joked: 'You could say Sweden is one-zero up already.'Rebekah Vardy reveals the England sex ban has been lifted...Share this articleThe country's FA general secretary Hakan Sjostrand chuckled: 'Yes we also have caviar on the menu, but that will be OK as long as England have their fish and chips.' Meanwhile Gareth Southgate's men will be staying on the outskirts next door to an Ibis hotel with a McDonalds nearby and traffic streaming outside and fridge magnets are on sale in the foyer for  £1.50. The Renaissance offers a range of salads, soups, grilled meat and fish in its 'Terrace' restaurant with its most pricey item being a grilled steak for £22.           England boss Gareth Southgate had no say in the hotel, which was chosen by FIFAHowever, England's players rarely eat in hotel restaurants and have their own food prepared for them by an official FA chef.The 196-room Renaissance was opened in 2003 with rates starting at £70 a night compared to the more expensive Lotte where the cheapest rooms are £200. But the standard of cotton sheets and the fine food will be forgotten once the teams do battle for a place in the World Cup semi-finals.Mr Nilsson, who was wearing his country's football short and is a Wolverhampton Wanderers fan, said: ' FIFA chose this hotel. So it is one-zero for us then.'We do have caviar, but I am pretty sure they can manage without caviar and it will be a good game. Otherwise they are welcome to visit us. It will be a fantastic match between two great teams.'He added: 'We had Netherlands and France in our (qualifying) group and we beat Italy in a play off. We beat Portugal last year in a friendly.          The Swedes are in the Lotte Hotel (pictured), which opened in April, and is the best hotel in the area where the cheapest rooms available at the moment are £200 per night          The Lotte's sumptuous fine food on offer even has its own caviar menu where a spoonful of Stugeon is available for £71 and a lesser 'Pike' variety for £16'And we won the group of four here which had Germany in it and we have just beaten Switzerland in Russia who are ranked sixth in the world…why shouldn't we be confident?'We also have the biggest respect for our opponents. But we go in to the quarter final in a very good mood.'  The Swedish delegation have been privately meeting human and civil rights leaders in Russia and supporting their work. Mr Sjostrand added: ' England have so many good players and they should beat us. But it would be so boring if life was always like that.'He said the Swedish fans would support England if Sweden is knocked out and added: 'Harry Kane is a fantastic player and we follow the Premier League in Sweden.    Despite Sweden claiming victory in the battle of the hotels, Gareth Southgate's men will be hoping for a repeat of their heroics when they beat Colombia on Tuesday (pictured)'I am a Manchester United supporter and one of my daughters is called Ester because of Manchester.' I also follow Ashley Young , Rashford and Lingard. England have so many good players.He said he expected between 1000 and1500 fans to be in the Samara Arena on Saturday evening to be supporting Sweden.He added 'To come here is a challenge because of a lack of flights and it is really expensive.'We had 500-6000 people at our last match because it was in St Petersburg and it not so difficult to travel from Sweden. People came by car and by train through Finland.'We hope for a great match and of course a Swedish victory. But overall, a fair match which will be great for the supporters and enjoyed by the world.'

title: How Jesse Lingard Englands King Social Media
story: This tweet by Jesse Lingard this week assured his place as the king of social media in the England team, whose image has been transformed by players' use of Instagram and Twitter          He is now turning his footballing and online prowess into a strong brand, based on his distinctive goal celebration, in which he spells out his initials with his hands          He is now busy building a brand around his celebration and his nickname 'JLingz'The public's love of the England team is a million miles from when Sam Allardyce lost his job as England manager  after he was filmed talking to undercover reporters posing as businessmen.Back then, confidence in the national team was at rock bottom.  But now, just two years on, England have rebuilt their public image, thanks to squeaky-clean Gareth Southgate and his squad of fresh-faced young players.Among them is 25-year-old Lingard, who, with four million Instagram followers, is at the head of a group of stars whose social media posts are watched by thousands of young fans.EXCLUSIVE: Sweden's WAGS will stay at the same hotel as the...EXCLUSIVE: Man dumped by Gareth Southgate's wife for England...Share this articleA social media hit this week came Jesse filmed fellow young player Trent Alexander-Arnold saying 'It's coming home' to him on the pitch after the Colombia victory.Lingard has also posted videos of himself dancing in his pants with Ruben Loftus-Cheek in the changing room, being shaved by teammates and celebrating with fans.Such videos give fans a players' eye view of the World Cup and take supporters inside the England camp in a way never seen before.     He is currently believed to be single after his relationship with Jena Frumes ended in scandal          Jena split from Jesse before tweeting: 'At least I can say I tried plus enjoyed the ride'          Lingard and Ms Frumes split up in March after she posed for steamy pictures in his shirtSocial media experts say his and other players' tweets and videos are building a new image for the national side, totally distinct from the days of 'dentist chair' drinkathons and Graham Taylor's 'turnips'.Former Twitter head of sport Lewis Wiltshire told The Daily Star: 'If there is a player who uses Instagram better or more effectively than Jesse Lingard, I'm yet to see them.'These players are from a generation where they understand and enjoy this stuff.'I'm convinced it's at the heart of why this England team's public image is different from, say, 10 years ago.'Mr Wiltshire says he doesn't believe a representative handles Jesse's social media for him, as with other players, which may be part of its success.The Manchester United midfielder could now use his performances in the World Cup to launch a strong Beckham-like 'brand'.He has used Instagram to give fans a players-eye view of the World Cup, including video of him dancing in his pants in the changing room  He stays close to his grandmother and grandfather, who helped get him into football as a childThree weeks before the tournament, Lingard applied for four trademarks, three centred on his nickname 'JLingz' and another featuring his goal celebration, in which he holds his hands in front of his face and spells out his initials.He has since launched a clothing range, including caps, T-shirts and hoodies emblazoned with his goal celebration logo, which have already all sold out on his website jlingz.com.Andy Sutherden, head of sport  marketing at H+K Strategies, told CityAM: 'Jesse Lingard's team has acknowledged the fact that if he does well in Russia, there’s an immediate opportunity but one with a very short shelf life. 'They’re also understanding of the fact that people who become known for something different - think Crouch and the robot - extend their marketing appeal beyond the audience of sport.' Meanwhile, there are rumours that Manchester United bosses are set to increase his wages from £75,000 to £150,000 to keep other clubs from trying to tempt him away.          The 25-year-old midfielder is one of a new generation of players who is savvy with social media          While communicating with his millions of Instagram followers, he has created a strong brand          He has now used the platform to launch a range of clothing, including these JLingz capsOne thing that makes his social media postings different from some of teammates is the lack of a girlfriend.He dated childhood sweetheart Emma Hyde for five years until he ended it in 2016.He later went out with glamorous US-based Instagram model Jena Frumes, but she dumped him after a tabloid newspaper revealed he had sex with an admin assistant from Sheffield in a hot tub.Jesse remains committed to his family, and even has a picture of his mother Kirsty, 49, in his room in Russia.As a boy he attended Beamont Community Primary school in Warrington, where most of the boys his age wanted to play rugby league.His grandfather Ken, a former GB power lifter, was the one who suggested he take up football and ferried him to training sessions and matches.    Before the World Cup, he made his nickname and goal celebration logo trademarks          Lingard's recently-released clothing range has already completely sold out on his websiteWorld Cup 2018: England's Jesse Lingard has trademarked his JLingz celebration — and he's done so at the perfect time | City A.M.

title: Lewis Hamilton says pet bulldog Roscoe earns 530 day model Los Angeles
story: Lewis Hamilton poses with his dog Roscoe. Hamilton might be the breadwinner but Roscoe brings home £560 per day as a model'He gets paid, $700 dollars a day, it's ridiculous and he gets his treat, he loves it.'Roscoe is so important to the F1 legend he has had his sperm frozen so after retirement he can use a breeder to get more puppies.          Roscoe enjoying the sunshine as he gets used to life in Los Angeles where he works as a model          Roscoe had to be snipped because he was ejaculating in his sleep. However, Hamilton had his sperm frozen Hound of the Brigade: Sherlock the forensic fire dog can...Share this articleThe bulldog cannot breed naturally after getting the snip after 'complications'. Roscoe had to be taken to the vet because he accidentally ejaculated in his sleep.Speaking to F1's 'Beyond The Grid' podcast, Hamilton said: 'The reason I had to get him snipped, is because, the poor guy would wake up randomly and he would ejaculate everywhere. He would get scared and wouldn't know what happened, it was so funny, but it was bad as it was everywhere.          'Sitting in on engineering with dad today' Lewis Hamilton's dog gets the inside scoop at his meetings           Roscoe on the beach! The bulldog travels around the world with Lewis Hamilton the F1 star           When in Rome: Roscoe poses in front of the Colosseum in Rome on yet another holiday           Roscoe and Coco cuddle up to their dog sitter in Los Angeles while Hamilton is away           Roscoe poses in the sunshine with a friend. The dog has a modelling career earning him thousands of dollars           Lewis Hamilton and dog Roscoe hanging out with friend Daniel Forrest, known as Spinz Beats in the USA'So he had to get the snip, but I can't not breed this boy, he is so handsome and has the kindest heart. At some stage we will get some puppies, so probably once when I retire from racing and have a family, I am definitely getting more Roscoes.'Hamilton who made a name for himself by racing past his competitors on the circuit is believed to be worth just shy of £200m.The now renowned Formula One star recently placed third at the 2018 Monaco Grand Prix. Though he fell just short of victory, his other accomplishments after more than a decade as a professional Formula One racer speak for themselves.          On the road again! Roscoe has 142,000 followers on Isntagram and makes money as a model           Bulldog Roscoe is often featured on Hamilton's social media. This post was captioned: 'Roscoe has the purest of hearts. A dogs love is second to none. Unconditional and unwavering'He is preparing for Silverstone, after he lost his championship lead to Sebastian Vettel in Austria. Hamilton is the highest-paid professional athlete in the United Kingdom. In 2012, he Mercedes's racing team in a staggering $100 million (£195.5 million) deal, making him one of Formula One's highest-paid drivers of all time.

title: Wilander backing Edmund upset Djokovic
story: Kyle Edmund won the first set against Novak Djokovic in his third round Wimbledon clash, starting minutes after England won a place in the World Cup semi finals          The Yorkshire player won the first set against three-time champion Novak Djokovic but eventually lost in four sets Those who had tickets for Saturday's tennis were issued with pink and blue re-entry wristbands so they could run back inside once the football action was over. Before the England match started there were chants of 'get the tennis off' as fans waited eagerly for the football to be put on the big screens.Clive McCabe, from Twickenham, had seats on Court One but left to watch the football when the Three Lions' match in Samara kicked off at 3pm British time. 'It's the most people who have left Wimbledon on middle Saturday between 1pm and 2pm. There's more people leaving than going in,' he said. Three Lions ROAR! England fans turn the streets of Samara...Up to 10,000 tickets go unsold for the England vs Sweden...Share this articleBefore that, fans could be seen knocking back pints and basking in the gorgeous sunshine as they got ready to cheer on Edmund, the last remaining British singles player at Wimbledon.Sir Bobby Charlton was also spotted signing autographs and joining in on the fun. He was joined by sporting stars including Sir Mo Farah, boxer David Haye, Dame Jessica Ennis-Hill and former cricketer Andrew Strauss, on another scorching day at Wimbledon.The All England Lawn Tennis Club (AELTC) announced on Friday that Edmund will play third on Centre Court, with the scheduling likely to avoid a clash between the tennis and football.Haye admitted he would be one of those trying to juggle the two sporting events.            Scores of fans left Wimbledon this afternoon in order to make it to a pub in time to watch England play against Sweden          This fan was streaming the England vs Sweden World Cup quarter final while sat at Centre Court to watch Rafael Nadal           Fans left the tennis to go and watch the football in the nearby Rose and Crown pub in Wimbledon village          One fan said more people were leaving the tennis than arriving ahead of England's World Cup quarter-final            Some fans were clearly more concerned with the football than the tennis and could be seen watching on their phones          Another fan proudly showed how they were streaming the World Cup quarter final on their phone rather than pay attention to what was happening on the court          This fan could be seen paying absolutely no attention to the tennis as he watched the World Cup match on his tablet on court number one          Even the legends and officials seemed to be getting involved as Rod Laver, Billy Jean King and Phillip Brook, AELTC Chairman, all appeared to be distracted          Sweden fans at Wimbledon look disappointed as they check the score and realise that their team are losing to England          An England fan screams in joy at Wimbledon as she hears Southgate's side had scored against Sweden in the World Cup          Hundreds of fans piled on to Henman Hill as they waited for Kyle Edmund to face three-time champion Novak Djokovic          Although the fans had come to watch the tennis, they could be seen unfurling England flags and wearing replica shirts          As fans flocked to watch the tennis, many were dressed in England football shirts ahead of the big World Cup tie on Saturday'I'll try, I dunno how,' he told the Press Association. 'We're going to do it, we're going to do it.'Tennis star Heather Watson, who is not due to play on Saturday, also appeared preoccupied by the football.She tweeted on Saturday: 'FOOTBALL IS COMING HOME.' However Sir Cliff Richard, a regular at Wimbledon, said he would not be focusing on England's quarter-final.'I'm watching tennis. I'm here for tennis,' he said as he arrived. 'I'll get the results later. I hope they do well.'    Edmund headed to Centre Court with his coach Fredrik Rosengren urging him to enjoy the moment in what is sure to be a difficult match.Edmund was spotted with an England flag yesterday, as he threw his support behind the England football team ahead of their crunch World Cup contest.And there may be some ision in the Edmund camp with Fredrik Rosengren being Swedish.  Olympic gold medal boxer Nicola Adams, who was also in the royal box, said: 'I'll be focusing on the tennis - and hopefully I'll get the updates later.'Asked if she had a message for Edmund and the England team, Adams said: 'Good luck, and I hope they do really well, they've done really good so far.'            British tennis number one Kyle Edmund, pictured, took the the time out to throw his support behind the England football team          It is set to be another scorching hot day today at Wimbledon, with maximum temperatures reaching 31C (88F), according to forecasters          Although it was mainly England fans at Wimbledon, Amanda Strang (pictured) is a Sweden fan who also looks set to enjoy Wimbledon ahead of the match          The influence of the football was widespread with a number of fans dressed in England shirts and looking in high spirits          Some England fans found a novel way to express their support for their country as they wore hats with a passionate Gareth Southgate on them           Sir Bobby Charlton was spotted visiting Wimbledon today despite the England vs Sweden World Cup quarter-final being just hours away          England and Liverpool footballer Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain missed the World Cup through injury and he was also at Wimbledon          The former World Cup winner and England legend joined a host of other sporting personalities to watch the tennis, with British number one Kyle Edmund set to take on Novak Djokovic          Fans could be seen enjoying the sun as they relaxed ahead of the big tennis clash which sees Edmund face Djokovic as Britain's last hope          There may be some ision in the Edmund camp with his coach, Fredrik Rosengren, being Swedish and his match starting an hour or so after the England tie          With Edmund and England's football team both in action today, fans are set for an exciting day of action and seemed to be well-set          Former England footballer Bobby Charlton and his wife Norma take their seat in the Royal box on Centre Court before watching Spain's Rafael Nadal play against Australia's Alex De Minaur          Jessica Ennis-Hill was another of the sporting royalty to take their place in the centre court Royal box at Wimbledon today, as they await Kyle Edmund's match          Former England cricket captain  Andrew Strauss was also in the royal box on centre court ahead of Edmund's crunch match          Olympic gold medalist swimmer Adam Peaty looked dapper in a white suit as he took his place in the Royal box today          Former Rugby legend Dr J P R Williams (pictured) is also on the royal box on centre court today,  on day six of the Wimbledon          Commentator Barry Davies also turned up to watch Edmund, with the 23-year-old British number one on court at 4.15pmIt was set to be a hot day at Wimbledon, with maximum temperatures of 31C (88F), forecasters said.Spectators were slapping on the sun cream with UV levels likely to become very high by mid-afternoon.And the football influence was clear at Wimbledon as several fans wore England shirts and brandished flags ahead of the  tie.Some could be seen enjoying a pint and basking in the sunshine as they flocked to Murray Mound ahead of the Edmund-Djokovic clash.   Coach Rosengren said: 'To play one of the best guys ever in tennis on the mostfamous court on home soil, in my opinion it can't be bigger than that.'That is something he has to be very proud of. He has achieved so much so it's great, but at the same time you have to find a balance of not being too excited,you go in and try to play to win. He is in unbelievably good shape mentally. We talk a lot about that, to enjoy it. Sometimes we all forget the joy of playing.'The shocks continued in the women's draw on Friday, with last year's runner-up Venus Williams and her American compatriot Madison Keys joining the exodus of top-10 seeds.Only Simona Halep and Karolina Pliskova remain, but Serena Williams is looming large after beating Kristina Mladenovic to reach round four. Roger Federer made it 29 consecutive sets won at Wimbledon as the men's draw remained much more predictable so far.           Judy Murray and Strictly dancer Neil Jones were also in attendance ahead of the match between Edmund and Djokovic          Former boxing world champion joined Sir Bobby Charlton as one of the sporting personalities visiting Wimbledon          Despite the football match which began at 3pm, thousands of fans turned up for the sixth day of action at Wimbledon today          Former England Rugby captain Chris Robshaw and singer Camilla Kerslake were among the stars attending day six  Coach Fredrik Rosengren wants Kyle Edmund to enjoy facing Novak Djokovic ahead of their contest on Centre Court today          Former Tennis players Billie Jean King and Rod Laver (pictured) were among the stars in the royal box on centre court today          Large groups of spectators could be seen queuing up in the sunshine ahead of an exciting day's play at Wimbledon (pictured)          With Andy Murray ruled out and all the British women eliminated, Kyle Edmund was Britain's last hope at the tournament

title: Streaming delay make England fans using phones irate waiting overdue flight
story: This morning, Neil Hall, the product team lead for BBC Sport warned users watching on mobile devices may face a 20 second delay compared to watching on BBC One. Hundreds of people took to Twitter to complain their stream was down in the last five minutes of the game. Neil Hall, the product team lead for BBC Sport said the delay was 'one of the big issues in emerging technology'. Three Lions ROAR! England fans turn the streets of Samara...'We'll make the nation proud': England captain Harry Kane...Share this articleA twenty second delay is significant. For example, in England's last match those watching on live TV would be celebrating victory while for those watching on a live stream, Eric Dier would still be approaching the goal.The number of people watching online and on mobile devices is on the rise, particularly with millennials and Generation Z viewers. Ahead of today's match, 43.5million people have already watched a live stream on the BBC - more than double that watched all games online during Euro 2016.            Up to 30 million people are expected to tune into today's game to see the Three Lions take on Sweden in the quarter finals of the World CupAround 45 percent of streams are through mobiles, a shift from years ago when people were streaming through fast broadband, Neil Hall told the Guardian.  People getting married today have been told to be vigilant of guests watching the game, as have theatre performers and even Wimbledon players.The World Cup will not be shown at Wimbledon, after images of Centre Court being deserted as fans even flocked from the match where Jenena Ostapenko was playing Katy Dunneto to catch the Three Lions play. BBC said: 'We're aware that some people were experiencing technical issues and are looking into the cause. We apologise to anyone who was affected.'          In England's last match those watching on live TV would be celebrating victory while for those watching on a live stream, Eric Dier would still be approaching the goal to take his winning penalty          Millions of people will tune in to watch the game live and in public spaces across the countryLivestream of England match will have 20-second delay, says BBC | Football | The Guardian

title: Eerie photos reveal streets motorways no traffic soulless Bluewater shopping centre

title: Englands run World Cup semi finals 1990 Gascoignes tears spoke nation
story: Paul Gascoigne cries during England's semi-final against West Germany in 1990, after he was shown a yellow card which would have made him ineligible for the final Margaret Thatcher's hold on power in the UK was beginning to loosen after more than a decade as Prime Minister, with the poll tax riots coming just months before the 1990 tournament. She would be out of office by the end of the year, replaced by John Major, while Iraq's invasion of Kuwait caused a crisis in the Middle East. Meanwhile, as the Eastern Bloc was convulsed by revolutions and political change, eventual winners West Germany were in the process of absorbing the communist East and completing the country's reunification after the fall of the Berlin Wall. ‘We can make history’: England’s hero goalkeeper Jordan...BBC iPlayer CRASHES in the last five minutes of England's...Share this articleElton John topped the charts in the UK with the re-released Sacrifice, a double A-side single with Healing Hands, which spent five weeks at the top including when England played West Germany. Ghost, starring Patrick Swayze and Demi Moore, was the highest grossing film in 1990 while other movies of note included Home Alone, Pretty Woman and Dances with Wolves. TV highlights in 1990 included debuts for Art Attack and Waiting for God, along with Countdown's 1,000th episode and the pilot episode of Mr Bean, which aired on January 1.           England's team in the semi: Gary Lineker, Paul Parker, Steve McMahon, Paul Gascoigne, John Barnes, Des Walker, Stuart Pearce, Chris Waddle, Mark Wright, Peter Shilton and Terry Butcher          West German captain Lothar Matthäus consoles Chris Waddle after his decisive penalty miss          David Platt celebrates after scoring a last-gasp winner against Belgium in the round of 16The first Wallace and Gromit film, A Grand Day Out, was nominated for Best Animated Short Film after its release in 1989.A heatwave hit the country a month after the World Cup finished.  A Leicester weather station recorded the highest temperature ever known in Britain of 99F (37.1C)  - one degree Fahrenheit higher than the previous record set in 1911.Meanwhile the Ford Fiesta was the top-selling car of the 1990s. Loose-fitting jeans, loose silhouettes and tie-dye were among the decade's top fashion trends. In footballing terms, Liverpool had just won their 18th - and most recent - league title.  Just as they have at this year's tournament, England had a generous run to the last four in Italy in 1990.They began the competition with two draws, as Ireland cancelled out Gary Lineker's goal to tie 1-1 in the opener before England played out a goalless match with the Netherlands. Bobby Robson's side ensured progress to the knockout stage when Derby's Mark Wright headed England's winner against Egypt. They defeated Belgium in the last 16 when David Platt hooked in a volley in extra time, with penalties looming, to give England a 1-0 win.      Crowds of fans fill the streets of Luton as they welcome the team home after the World Cup           Elton John was at number one with the re-released Sacrifice, a double A-side single with Healing Hands, which spent five weeks at the top including when England played Germany          Riot police clash with demonstrators at St Martin's Place in London during the poll tax protests  The pilot episode of Mr Bean, starring Rowan Atkinson (pictured), was released early in 1990John Motson's excitable commentary - 'England have won it, in the last minute of extra time!' - features in the lyrics of the original Three Lions, recorded in 1996. They fell behind to Cameroon in the quarter-final, before two penalties from Lineker, including the winner in extra time, sent England into the last four with a 3-2 win. It was their first appearance in the semi-finals since their victory in 1966 after more than two decades of underachievement by the national side.  England faced the first penalty shootout in their history in the semi-final against West Germany. England's semi-final  was shown by both the BBC and ITV, the BBC beating its rival by two to one (16.7 million watched BBC One, 8.5 million ITV).  Londoners enjoy the heatwave which hit the country shortly after the World Cup finished          People paddle in a fountain at Trafalgar Square in London as they enjoy the 1990 heatwave           Ford Fiestas (pictured) were the most popular car of the 1990s in the UK It remains England's most-watched World Cup game in their history.  They fell behind to a deflected free kick early in the second half, but Lineker's fourth goal of the tournament drew the game level with ten minutes left.  Winning the hearts of the nation, Paul Gascoigne burst into tears when he was shown a yellow card during extra time, which would have ruled him out of the final if England had reached it. England scored the first three kicks in their shootout but Stuart Pearce was denied by the West German keeper before Chris Waddle missed the target completely, sending England out. The Germans went on to beat Argentina in a scrappy final, winning their last tournament as a ided nation, while England lost the third-place playoff 2-1 against Italy, who had also exited on penalties.

story: Mohamed Abdel-Khalek and his wife Aila built a carp pond in their garden in Boston, Lincolnshire, which became the centre of a three-year legal battle at The Brewsters grew enraged over the noise of a pump for the pond and leakages from the new water feature, which is just a few feet from their bungalow.The issues were resolved but the feud escalated when the Brewsters took offence at plastic herons, a Santa Claus figure and a 1.5ft Saudi Arabian flag that the Abdel-Khaleks – who were given retrospective planning permission for the pond in 2016 – hung above the pond. story: Thames Water has warned customers to conserve water ahead of the imposition of a possible hosepipe ban having endured the third driest June in more than a century          Several utility companies have warned customers they may introduce a hosepipe banUnited Utilities, which serves seven million customers in the North West, has warned it may impose a hosepipe ban in the coming days because of reducing water supplies.The situation is unlikely to improve with forecasters predicting no significant rainfall across England until at least Friday, with only occasional light showers between now and then.Boris in four-letter attack on May: Foreign Secretary stuns...Voters back Theresa May over her Brexit deal but Labour has...Share this articleAs a result, Thames Water – which insists it is not enforcing a hosepipe ban – is among several firms urging customers to cut down their water use to combat the dry weather. title: Parents Thai boys trapped underground write letters coach
story: Parents of the 12 boys trapped in a cave in Thailand insist their coach Ekkapol Chantawong, 25, should not blame himself for leading them insideThe 25-year-old has profusely apologised to the parents of the boys under his care, but they refuse to let him beat himself up.'Please don't blame yourself,' the mother of Nattawut Takamsai, 14, wrote to Mr Chantawong in one of the first letter sent to the boys inside.'We want you to know that no parents are angry with you at all, so don't you worry about that.' Mr Chantawong earlier issued a humbling apology to the parents and vowed look after their loved-ones 'to the best of my ability'. Ms Takamsai then turned her attention to the children, giving them a similar message of support to keep them going.'To all the kids. We are not mad at you at all. Do take good care of yourself. Don't forget to cover yourself with blankets as the weather is cold. We're worried. You will come out soon,' she wrote.          Mr Chantawong earlier issued a humbling apology to the parents and vowed look after their loved-ones 'to the best of my ability'The letter was in response to heart-rending notes of love from the stranded Thai footballers to their anxious parents waiting for their rescue from the flooded cave.The letters were delivered by ers and emerged on Friday night. The missing boys urge their mothers and fathers not to worry about them and say they are being well looked-after by their Thai Navy Seal 'brothers', who are coordinating the evacuation from the Tham Luang cavern.The youngsters beg their teachers not to bombard them with homework after their escape and list dishes they long to eat when they emerge from their underground prison.          Thai military personnel inside a cave complex during the ongoing rescue operations for the youth soccer team and their assistant coach, at Tham Luang cave in Khun Nam Nang Non Forest Park          Thail soldiers and police officers are seen as rescue operations continue for the 12 boys and their football team coach trapped in Tham Luang cave at Khun Nam Nang Non Forest Park          The young Thai footballers trapped in the Tham Luang cave have written these heartfelt messages to their parents           The 12 boys and their soccer coach have been found alive in the cave where they've been missing for over a week after monsoon rains blocked the main entranceWith tear-jerking simplicity the boys from the Wild Boar football club say they want to go 'straight home', in a collective letter from all 12.And they appeal to their parents, grand-parents, brothers and sisters not to worry about them in inidual letters from each boy.'We are all strong, do not worry about us. When we are out we want to eat so many things,' the boys wrote in a collective letter.'When we are out we would like to go straight home. And we beg the teacher not to give us a lot of homework.'  In the inidual letters, one boy apologies to his parents for being away so long and promises to help them run their shop.Another boy asks his brother to take him out for fried chicken and another asks his parents to take him to a barbecue restaurant.A glimpse into the damp conditions and terror experienced by the youngsters for the past two weeks is revealed in just a few words as one boys says he 'hopes' to get out and another describes how cold it is inside the flooded cave.Others simply tell their families how much they love and miss them.One asks his parents not to forget his birthday.  'I'm trying to get out of here as quickly as possible': Ekkarat's touching letter to parents  Keeper: Ekkarat Wongsookchan, 14, is also known as 'Bew' and is a goalkeeperEkkarat Wongsukjan, 14, wrote: 'Mum and dad, don't worry about me.'I'm only away for two weeks.'When I'm out I will help you work in the shop.'I'm trying to get out of here as quickly as possible.'  'Don't worry about me - I'm safe now': Sompong's letter to mother and father  Harry Kane fan: The family of Sompong 'Pong' Jaiwong say the sports-mad teenager is cheering on England to win the World CupSompong Jaiwong, 13, wrote: 'Dear mum and dad, I love you'Don't worry about me. I am safe now. I love you.'  Thai cave boys will NOT be coming out tonight: Rescuers plan...Headcam footage shows what it¿s like for Thai cave rescuers...Share this article  'Please take me for a barbecue when I get out': Pipat's plans for after he escapes the cave      Pipat is reportedly not a player for Wild Boar FC, but had joined the team for practice session before they embarked on their trek to the cavesPipat Phothi, 15, wrote: 'Mum and Dad,'I love you and my little sibling.'If I manage to get out could you please take me a barbecue restaurant.'I love you dad, mum and sibling.'  'Please tell my teacher that I am OK': Mongkol urges his mother not to worry    Leader and newbie: Duangpetch Promthep, 13, left, is the team captain of Wild Boar FC, while Mongkol Boonpiam, 14, right, joined just a year agoMongkol Boonpiam, 13, asked: 'Mum are you at home? How are you?'I am fine.'Please tell my teacher that I am ok.'I love you mum.'  'The Navy Seals brothers are taking care of us': Panumas sends parents his love    'Ideal defender': Panumas 'Mick' Saengdee, 13 has been praised by his coaches for his skillsPanumas Saengdee, 13, wrote: 'Don't worry about me.'I miss everyone. I miss grandpa, auntie, mum, dad and all my brothers and sisters.'I love you all.'I'm ok inside here.'The Navy Seals brothers are taking care of use very, very well.'I love you all.  'It's a little cold in here!': Duangphet reminds his parents not to forget his birthday    Leader and newbie: Duangpetch Promthep, 13, is the team captain of Wild Boar FCDuangphet Promthep, 13, wrote: 'I am good but it's a little bit cold here.'Don't worry about me.'And don't forget to organize a birthday party for me.'  'Please tell my brother to take me for fried chicken!': Pornchai's message to family      Prajak Sutham's,  grandmother of footballer Kiangkham Janthapoon, holds a photo of him with his parents when he was aged 2With tear-jerking emotion, the mother of Chanin Wiboonrungruang said: 'Mum is waiting for you outside. I love you and I miss you a lot.'Be patient and keep on fighting. You must be strong.  I am waiting for you.We must make it out. I believe you can make it. I am here to support you. I love you very much. Daddy loves you too. We love you a lot.'In her letter the mother of Mongkol Boonpiam wrote: 'Mummy is waiting for you outside the cave. I miss you.'Don't feel pity for yourself, I really love you. Please take care of yourself.'          Ratdao Chantapoon (far left), Mother of Prajak Sutham,prays with other mothers during a vigil in the Tham Luang Forest Park in Chiang Rai ProvinceThe grandfather of Panumas Saengdee, Grandpa Lek, said: 'I wish all of you and the coach to be strong.I wait for you outside. I hope you stay healthy.Don't be afraid that anyone will blame you. I don't blame you. I love you always.'The parents of Adul Sam-on wrote: 'Mum and dad really want to see your face again. We pray for you and your friends.'We want to see you as soon as possible. When you get out of the cave please thank all the rescuers. Trust in God.'Don't worry about anything. Dad and mum will be here until you get out.' And in their joint letter to the coach they asked him to bring their beloved children out safely.The wrote: 'We would like to thank you for taking care of our children. Don't blame yourself. 'Do not worry.    'We are not angry with you at all. We understand the situation and would like to give your our moral support.'Thank you again for taking care of your little brothers.'You went there together and you will come out together. Please bring them out safely.'We are waiting for you all here outside the cave.' And the coach Ekkapol's aunt added no one was blaming him. She wrote: 'I am waiting for you outside the cave. Don't trouble yourself. Take care of yourself.No-one blames you. Auntie, grandma and all of the family are waiting for you outside. Fight on.We are supporting you. We miss you. No one blames you.Many people are giving you moral support. Fight on.I love you. Please bring your little brothers out.'

title: Brexiteers blame Michael Gove leading betrayal referendum
story: Michael Gove (pictured today on Marr) was lashed as the 'snake in the grass' responsible for betraying the referendum today - but he insisted May's Brexit blueprint does honour the vote          The Environment Secretary admitted to Andrew Marr (pictured) the draft plans agreed at Friday's showdown were a balance between Leave and Remain ministers - but insisted the Government had resolved not to make 'perfect the enemy of the good'          As accounts of what happened at Chequers on Friday continued to emerge today, the Environment Secretary was slammed as a 'busted flush' after it was revealed he spoke up for Theresa May's (pictured today in Maidenhead) soft Brexit blueprintBut speaking to the BBC's Andrew Marr today, Mr Gove said his actions had been those of a 'realist'.Asked if the deal was all he hoped for, Mr Gove said: 'No, but then I'm a realist and one of the things about politics is you mustn't, you shouldn't make the perfect the enemy of the good.'One of the things about this compromise is that it unites the Cabinet.'He added: 'All those of us who believe that we want to execute a proper Brexit, and one that is the best deal for Britain, have an opportunity now to get behind the Prime Minister in order to negotiate that deal.'Russia are dumped out of World Cup after host nation loses...Is this the worst parenting ever? Man takes on bull with a...Share this articleMr Gove said the draft deal would mean Britain was outside of the European Court and the political structures of the EU.He said the common rule book would mean unified rules for 20 per cent of the British economy dealing with goods - but that Parliament was not obliged to follow new rules in future.And he said Britain's innovative services sector would be free from EU interference.  All of the Brexiteers in the Cabinet signed off on the plans on Friday night - even Mr Johnson despite telling the meeting it was a 'turd'. Eurosceptic MPs lashed the ministers today.One Brexiteer lashed Mr Gove as 'the main snake in the grass', after he spoke up in favour of Mrs May's plan during a 12-hour meeting of the Cabinet at Chequers.           Anger at Mrs May's proposals was growing today. Veteran Brexiteer Sir Bill Cash (pictured today on Sky News) said the proposals left 'a lot of questions'Another senior MP told the Telegraph: 'They should have spoken for Britain.'They failed. They are selfish iniduals who put career before country. 'It is pretty bloody obvious they prefer their ministerial cars.'Mr Gove's decision may backfire and destroy his rekindled leadership ambitions. 'His pretensions to being a credible leader have been blown to smithereens,' said one senior Brexiteer to the paper.'He's a busted flush.' An ally of Mr Johnson said: 'There is no doubt we would be heading for an even softer Brexit had Boris not been around the table.' Anger at Mrs May's proposals was growing today.Veteran Brexiteer Sir Bill Cash said the proposals left 'a lot of questions' and warned the Prime Minister a confidence vote was unstoppable if 48 Tory MPs write to 1922 Committee chairman Graham Brady.Sir Bill told Sky News: 'There's a lot of unhappiness.. is this going to be a proper Brexit?'     Boris Johnson, pictured left, stunned fellow ministers with a four-letter dismissal of Theresa May's Brexit plan during Friday's Chequers meeting after Mrs May, right, called for loyaltyToday's accounts of Friday's showdown revealed Foreign Secretary Mr Johnson stunned fellow Ministers with his four-letter dismissal of the Prime Minister's plan at Friday's special Chequers summit designed to unite the Cabinet. His comment risks making him the first victim of Mrs May's fresh crackdown on dissent.Mr Johnson – who has been accused of betrayal by Tory Brexiteers for not blocking Mrs May's 'soft Brexit' proposals – spoke out against the plan for the UK to remain in Bline with Brussels rules in a new free trade zone with the EU.According to a reliable source, he complained that anyone obliged to defend the proposals would be 'polishing a turd'.He added sarcastically: 'Luckily we have some expert turd polishers' – shooting a glance at one of Mrs May's spin doctors.Challenging the Prime Minister's new policy to her face, he said that her decision to try to 'align' UK trading rules with the EU would reduce Britain to the humiliating status of a 'vassal state'.He also took issue with her cher-ished new customs plan, the Facilitated Customs Arrangement (FCA), claiming it would be a 'serious inhibitor' to striking new trade deals with non-EU countries.His outburst was revealed just hours after Mrs May tried to draw a red line under weeks of open dissent from her Ministers, vowing that from now on she will enforce collective Cabinet responsibility and sack any Ministers who defy her. Some senior Tories believe she may be forced to fire Mr Johnson.    The outburst was revealed hours after Mrs May threatened to sack disloyal ministersA Mail on Sunday poll today endorses her handling of the Cabinet showdown, with 33 per cent of voters supporting her Brexit plan and 23 per cent opposing it. The Survation poll, the first survey since the Chequers summit, suggests Mrs May has twice the support of Mr Johnson – although voters do not believe her plan is 'faithful' to the EU referendum result.Last night, Eurosceptic Tories said there was so much anger at the PM's 'sell-out' that some MPs would submit no-confidence letters to force a challenge to her leadership.And Jacob Rees-Mogg's pro-Brexit European Research Group said experts believe the Chequers deal left the UK 'on course for a 'black hole' Brexit' – meaning we would be sucked into the orbit of EU rules with no hope of escape.          Boris Johnson has launched an extraordinary four-letter attack on PM Theresa May over her Brexit plansMr Johnson made clear in the run-up to Friday's session that he was vehemently against any scheme which left us shackled to EU rules, leading to fears in Downing Street that he and other pro-Brexit Ministers could resign.But Mrs May launched her own plan to kill off his revolt: signalling in advance she had already lined up 'talented' junior Ministers to replace any Cabinet quitters forcing all those at the summit to hand over their phones to stop them briefing against her under the table and issuing an official No 10 communique declaring victory while her critics were still stuck inside arguing.          Tory MP Andrew Bridgen has accused Boris Johnson of raising the white flag over BrexitThis so-called Brexit deal is nothing short of a betrayal of the 17.4 million people who voted to leave the EU. What on earth were the staunch Leavers in the Cabinet doing?Where was Boris Johnson? At Chequers on Friday, we needed him to emulate his hero, Winston Churchill. Instead, he gave us a modern-day version of Neville Chamberlain.Sadly, the Foreign Secretary was not alone in apparently waving the white flag of appeasement in the direction of Brussels. Other Brexiteer buccaneers and recent Brexit converts also jumped ship.The door to Mrs May's country residence was open but they chose not to walk out of it. Perhaps the threat of the withdrawal of the Government limo was just too great.This is a huge mistake on two grounds. Firstly, all those harbouring leadership hopes have done their ambitions fatal harm. Grassroots party members will have no truck with their perceived treachery. Some will try to keep their leadership hopes alive by claiming it was not the time to quit and they had a duty to stay on to ensure Brexit is not further watered down. But it leaves only one credible contender with the integrity and backbone to follow Mrs May: Jacob Rees-Mogg.Secondly, Brexiteer Cabinet Ministers are losing their nerve at the wrong time. This is not the end of the battle – it is the start of the real fight for a true Brexit. What Theresa May unveiled last week appears little short of a punishment Brexit, designed by the EU to dissuade any other country from leaving the bloc.With no incentive to offer non-EU countries free trade deals when we leave, through mutual recognition of standards, the UK will forever remain a captive market for overpriced EU goods. It means going through the pretence of leaving but becoming a non-voting associate member, a vassal state.We would still be locked into the EU's suffocating embrace via this 'common rule book' while the dead hand of the European Court of Justice will be lurking in the background.In contrast, we should call Brussels' bluff and, if necessary, leave without a formal deal. A so-called 'no deal' scenario may sound scary but 'no deal' does not actually mean no deal. It simply means the UK would trade on WTO terms which we use already to trade with most of the world.The fight to deliver a proper Brexit starts here and now. How Brexiteers' hopes were shattered by a single meeting

title: Businesses slam Theresa Mays Brexit blueprint complicated
story: The new letter was coordinated by Richard Reed (file image) the founder of Innocent Drinks More than 100 business leaders and entrepreneurs dismissed Theresa May's Brexit blueprint and demanded an even softer exit.The group - which includes the founders of Innocent Drinks, Pret a Manger and Waterstones - complained about the 'cost, complexity and bureaucracy' proposed.  The Prime Minister won the backing of her Cabinet on Friday for a hybrid proposal that effectively creates a a common market on goods but would leave Britain free in other areas.Business figures want her to go even further and stay inside the EU customs union - and hope to bolster a Remain Tory rebellion in the Commons next week. At the same time the draft deal - which has not been put to Brussels yet - has been lashed by Brexiteers as betraying the EU referendum.Brexiteers blast 'snake in the grass' Gove for backing May's...A soft Brexit will see an even bigger landslide LABOUR...Share this articleThe letter, revealed by the Observer and Sunday Times today, was organised by Richard Reed, a co-founder of Innocent Drinks.It has been signed by the founders of Pret a Manger, Waterstones, Zoopla, Net-a-Porter, Domino's Pizza, Yo! Sushi and Jack Wills.It states: 'The cost, complexity and bureaucracy created by crashing out of the customs union and adopting alternative arrangements is the last thing that our businesses need as we seek to grow and employ more people.'It would amount to the British government tying the hands of British business.'          The group - which includes the founders of Innocent Drinks, Pret a Manger (pictured is boss Julian Metcalfe) and Waterstones - complained about the 'cost, complexity and bureaucracy' proposed          The chief of Domino's Pizza (file image also signed up tot the plan backing continued membership of the customs union The letter urges MPs to 'put aside party political and ideological interests' by backing amendments tabled by the Conservative MP Anna Soubry and Labour's Chuka Umunna.Mr Umunna said Britain was heading for a 'bad Brexit deal' and the amendments were a 'last chance for parliament to put the brakes on.          The Prime Minister (pictured today in Maidenhead) won the backing of her Cabinet on Friday for a hybrid proposal that effectively creates a a common market on goods but would leave Britain free in other areas.He said: 'That is why we are working with colleagues in all parties  those who support a people's vote on the final Brexit deal, as I do, as well as those who want a Brexit deal that does the least damage to British businesses which keep people in work.'Veteran Brexiteer Sir Bill Cash said the proposals left 'a lot of questions' and warned the Prime Minister a confidence vote was unstoppable if 48 Tory MPs write to 1922 Committee chairman Graham Brady.Sir Bill told Sky News: 'There's a lot of unhappiness.. is this going to be a proper Brexit?'   Tory Remainers have broadly welcomed progress towards a softer Brexit.Writing in the Observer today, Tory Nicky Morgan, who chairs the all-party Treasury select committee, says the proposed free-trade area 'sounds remarkably like the common market'.In a dig at Johnson, who reportedly commented 'f*** business' when reacting to claims that some firms would take jobs abroad, Ms Morgan said: 'The cabinet have very deliberately chosen to listen to business and not swear at them or ask them to keep quiet.'That is good for our future prosperity.' title: Wilander backing Edmund upset Djokovic

title: Streaming delay make England fans using phones irate waiting overdue flight
story: This morning, Neil Hall, the product team lead for BBC Sport warned users watching on mobile devices may face a 20 second delay compared to watching on BBC One. Hundreds of people took to Twitter to complain their stream was down in the last five minutes of the game. Neil Hall, the product team lead for BBC Sport said the delay was 'one of the big issues in emerging technology'. Three Lions ROAR! England fans turn the streets of Samara...'We'll make the nation proud': England captain Harry Kane...Share this articleA twenty second delay is significant. For example, in England's last match those watching on live TV would be celebrating victory while for those watching on a live stream, Eric Dier would still be approaching the goal.The number of people watching online and on mobile devices is on the rise, particularly with millennials and Generation Z viewers. Ahead of today's match, 43.5million people have already watched a live stream on the BBC - more than double that watched all games online during Euro 2016.            Up to 30 million people are expected to tune into today's game to see the Three Lions take on Sweden in the quarter finals of the World CupAround 45 percent of streams are through mobiles, a shift from years ago when people were streaming through fast broadband, Neil Hall told the Guardian.  People getting married today have been told to be vigilant of guests watching the game, as have theatre performers and even Wimbledon players.The World Cup will not be shown at Wimbledon, after images of Centre Court being deserted as fans even flocked from the match where Jenena Ostapenko was playing Katy Dunneto to catch the Three Lions play. BBC said: 'We're aware that some people were experiencing technical issues and are looking into the cause. We apologise to anyone who was affected.' title: England fans queue outside pubs FIVE hours watch World Cup clash Sweden
story: An England fan pulls up her top while standing on the bonnet of an ambulance in Borough, London, as other revellers gasp in awe    Three Lions supporters around the country celebrated wildly as England brilliantly beat Sweden 2-0 in the World Cup quarter final          Several celebrating fans jumped on the bonnet of an emergency vehicle in Borough High Street, leaving it severely dented - much to the annoyance of London Ambulance          'Obviously we are chuffed with the result this afternoon but there is absolutely NO excuse to vandalise emergency service vehicles by jumping on them,' it wrote on TwitterSergeant Wayne Baker, with West Yorkshire Police, tweeted his disgust after pictures emerged of revellers dancing on top of an ambulance in central London.He wrote: 'When I see behaviour like this it makes me anything but proud to be English .... You are a total disgrace. As for our National Football Team ... that does make me proud to be English!'  London Ambulance Service published images of the damage to the vehicle.They wrote: 'We're delighted with the result, but this has put a big dampener on the celebrations for us: while our officer attended a call nearby, this car was damaged in Borough High Street during the celebrations after the game, it's now off the road to be repaired.'Several celebrating fans jumped on the bonnet of an emergency vehicle in Borough High Street, leaving it severely dented - much to the annoyance of London Ambulance.'Obviously we are chuffed with the result this afternoon but there is absolutely NO excuse to vandalise emergency service vehicles by jumping on them,' it wrote on Twitter.'This vehicle is now off the road and unable to respond to patients. We are better than this England.'  A spokesman for the Met said there had not been a spike in call-outs, despite the hysteria following England's victory over Sweden.           London Ambulance Service published images of the damage to the vehicle - saying they were delighted with the result but not the actionsThe antics were in contrast to more responsible fans who were cheering, singing and jumping around celebrating the 2-0 win over Sweden while dousing one another in beer as they celebrated the goals.They had queued up for four hours outside pubs in boiling heat to watch the Three Lions take on Sweden in their quarter final clash.Other excited fans got excited at England's first semi-final qualifier since 1990, and participated in some over-the-top antics frowned upon by authorities.Other fans were seen riding on the bonnet of a car driving through a street crowded with celebrating revellers soon after England's victory  The driver, who clearly couldn't see past the men blocking his windscreen, almost crashed into a a family crossing the street with their dog. story: As the squad head to their first semi-final since 1990, Kensington Palace congratulated them on today's win.The Duke of Cambridge tweeted: 'You wanted to make history and you are doing just that.           The 25-year-old defender's first goal at international level could prove to be an important one as England look to reach their first semi-final in 28 years          A royal rendition of Three Lions was played in front of Buckingham Palace as England headed into the quarter-finals today'This has been an incredible #WorldCup run and we’ve enjoyed every minute. You deserve this moment – Football’s Coming Home! W.' The Three Lions took the lead today thanks to Harry Maguire, who met an Ashley Young corner to fire the ball into the back of the net.‘We can make history’: England’s hero goalkeeper Jordan...One man's ambition, decency and steel has changed English...Share this articleDefender Kieran Trippier - who has created 12 chances for England this World Cup - was praised by his father, who told MailOnline at the final whistle: ‘I’m so proud of my son, now he’s in the World Cup semi-final. I used to watch him play in a park in Bury, England are going to win.’ After surviving an early scare early in the second half England soon had their second, with Dele Alli heading home Jesse Lingard's first-time, curling cross. title: Harry Kane FaceTimes pregnant fiance UK
story: Harry Kane, pictured, FaceTimed his pregnant fiance Katie Goodland minutes after leading England to victory and onto their first World Cup semi final since Italia '90          Kane will lead England to the country's first World Cup semi-final since Italia '90          Kane joined some fans in the stand after the match in the Samara Arena Speaking after the game, Kane said: 'We looked composed. We looked like we controlled the game.'I know the fans here are enjoying it. The fans at home, I'm sure we'll see some videos tonight of them enjoying it.'Today's victory is the first time England have made it to the a World Cup semi final since Italia 90 when Bobby Robson's men lost out on penalties to West Germany.Share this article He said: 'So much preparation went into it and I thought we were fantastic today. It was a difficult game, Sweden made it tough - long balls, different to what we have faced so far.'We were brilliant at set-pieces, crosses into the box and we are buzzing.' We just have to go again, keep doing what we are doing and make the country proud.'Members of the squad, such as Jordan Pickford, Jordan Henderson and Jesse Lingard celebrated with family members in the stand. Eric Dier delighted one young fan by handing over his match shirt after the final whistle.            Jamie Vardy, left, who was on the bench for today's game, celebrated with his wife Rebekah          Jordan Henderson, pictured, celebrates with his family after today's game          Henderson celebrates after England reached the World Cup semis for the first time since 1990          Jesse Lingard also went over to his family to celebrate today's historic victory           Jordan Pickford went over to Megan Davison after keeping a clean sheet at the Samara Arena          Kane happily poses for photographs following today's victory against Sweden in Samara          Harry Maguire, who scored his first international goal in the first half also went to see his family in the stand,          Jamie Vardy, signed the jersey of a young fan following the game in the Samara Arena          John Stones and Millie Savage after England beat Sweden in Saturday's quarter-final

title: Swedens gracious ambassador congratulates England victory
story: Videos posted on social media showed England fans had taken over a London branch of IKEA           'Congratulations England. You had the stronger team today, and a great goalkeeper,' he saidThe victory sent English fans across the country into a frenzy, raucously celebrating England's booking a place in a World Cup semi-final for the first time in 28 years.Videos posted on social media showed England fans had taken over a branch of IKEA in the Westfield shopping centre in Stratford, east London.‘We can make history’: England’s hero goalkeeper Jordan...EXCLUSIVE: Harry Kane FaceTimes his pregnant fiance in UK as...Russia are dumped out of World Cup after host nation loses...Share this articleOne clip showed singing fans wreaking havoc inside the Swedish furniture store, as helpless staff look on.Some are seen jumping on beds in the retailer's showroom while others wave flags and throw cushions.MailOnline has contacted IKEA for comment.One clip showed singing fans wreaking havoc inside the Swedish furniture storeMeanwhile, the Swedish ambassador not only congratulated the team as a whole – as well as singling out goalkeeper Jordan Pickford for praise – but also pledged to support England in the next round. title: Stop carping Judge orders neighbours aside bitter feud garden pond
story: Mohamed Abdel-Khalek and his wife Aila built a carp pond in their garden in Boston, Lincolnshire, which became the centre of a three-year legal battle at The Brewsters grew enraged over the noise of a pump for the pond and leakages from the new water feature, which is just a few feet from their bungalow.The issues were resolved but the feud escalated when the Brewsters took offence at plastic herons, a Santa Claus figure and a 1.5ft Saudi Arabian flag that the Abdel-Khaleks – who were given retrospective planning permission for the pond in 2016 – hung above the pond. They claim they were to protect their koi carp but the Brewsters said they were put up to ‘intimidate’ them.Police officer is given the all-clear after being assessed...Is this the worst parenting ever? Man takes on bull with a...Share this articleThe Brewsters repeatedly complained to the police and Boston Borough Council about the ‘offensive’ items, claiming that retired eye surgeon Dr Abdel-Khalek, 67, who was born in Egypt but has lived in worked in the UK for more than 30 years, and his wife, born in the UK, were extremists.They also rang the Saudi embassy to get a translation of writing on the Saudi flag.Dr Abdel-Khalek then accused Mr Brewster, a solicitor who specialises in land development, of spying on his family. title: Thames Water begs customers not use water unnecessarily
story: Thames Water has warned customers to conserve water ahead of the imposition of a possible hosepipe ban having endured the third driest June in more than a century          Several utility companies have warned customers they may introduce a hosepipe banUnited Utilities, which serves seven million customers in the North West, has warned it may impose a hosepipe ban in the coming days because of reducing water supplies.The situation is unlikely to improve with forecasters predicting no significant rainfall across England until at least Friday, with only occasional light showers between now and then.Boris in four-letter attack on May: Foreign Secretary stuns...Voters back Theresa May over her Brexit deal but Labour has...Share this articleAs a result, Thames Water – which insists it is not enforcing a hosepipe ban – is among several firms urging customers to cut down their water use to combat the dry weather. On Friday evening, the firm texted thousands of customers in Slough, Wycombe and Aylesbury, saying: ‘Your support required: Water supply risk in your area. To keep taps running please do not use sprinklers &amp hoses, &amp use as little as you can. Thank you.’The company, which supplies 3.5 million households, is also advertising on billboards on the M25 and in shopping centres asking customers to: ‘Do your bit to save water.’ It has also pumped an extra 25 per cent of water into the local network – enough to fill 15 Olympic-sized swimming pools every day – and says a fleet of six tankers have been topping up Ashendon reservoir, near Aylesbury, with 430,000 litres of drinking water every day.England is set to bask in temperatures hotter than Lisbon today, with areas of the south hitting 32C. On Monday, temperatures will be slightly cooler but it will remain warm.
